discussion.content: Answer C- REST is the conventional way of interacting with information resources. REST is centered around an abstraction know as a "resource". Any named piece of information can be a resource.
C is the correct answer here

questions.question_text: Which is a valid description of REST?

choices.C: REST is the conventional way of interacting with information resources.
choices.A: REST provides the same architectural properties as SOAP.
choices.B: REST is a library that is part of JEE called JAX-RS.
choices.D: REST is a Web Services standard supported by JEE and JAX-RS.

discussion.content: Answer D. @Dependent scope is a default scope if none is specified. it means that an object exists to serve exactly one client and has the same lifecycle as the client.

choices.C: for the lifetime of the session
choices.D: for the lifetime of the Service object
choices.B: for the lifetime of the request
choices.A: for the lifetime of the enterprise application

questions.question_text:
You want to allow one set of roles to POST to a resource and another set of roles to GET it.
Which two configuration options should you use? (Choose two.)

choices.B: a single @HttpMethodContstraint annotation and a map of method to roles
choices.C: two <web-resource-collection> with different <http-method> in the deployment descriptor
choices.D: a single <web-resource-collection> with two <auth-constraint> with different <http-method> in the deployment descriptor
choices.A: two separate @HttpMethodConstraints annotations and sets of roles

questions.question_text:
You have been asked to implement internationalization in your JSF web application.
Where do you configure the supported locales?

discussion.content:
Correct answer is C. 
FacesConfig.xml - configure
<f:view> tag - set locale

choices.A: in the <f:view> tag of the Facelet page

discussion.content: Answer A. Multiple resources can be defined together using @javax.annotation.Resources annotation
